Headline: Welcome to Big Android BBQ Europe 2015
Text: Doors open / registration

Headline: Steve Kondik (Cyanogen) delivers Keynote at BABBQ Europe
Text:
Steve Kondik

Steve Kondik is going to discuss the evolution and direction of the current mobile platforms. In today‚Äôs industry, devices are only a small portion of the product, leaving the experience and feel to the operating system that drives the hardware. Cyanogen himself is going to discuss the intricacies and complexities behind driving a better and more user friendly experience.
Speaker: Steve Kondik
Description: Steve Kondik is going to discuss the evolution and direction of the current mobile platforms. In today‚Äôs industry, devices are only a small portion of the product, leaving the experience and feel to the operating system that drives the hardware. Cyanogen himself is going to discuss the intricacies and complexities behind driving a better and more user friendly experience.

Headline: How to not disable SELinux on Android
Text:
R√©my Gottschalk, & Guillaume Vercout√®re

SELinux is an access control mechanism integrated in the Linux kernel. The presentation starts with a short introduction to SELinux and its impact on Android. R√©my & Guillaume will show the best practices to grant a service new access rights under SELinux. SELinux has been progressively making its way to Android. It can be a pain to configure but is now here to stay. Because disabling SELinux is never a solution, R√©my & Guillaume started to study it‚Äôs mechanism as they worked on rom cooking.
Speaker: R√©my Gottschalk & Guillaume Vercout√®re
Description: SELinux is an access control mechanism integrated in the Linux kernel. The presentation starts with a short introduction to SELinux and its impact on Android. R√©my & Guillaume will show the best practices to grant a service new access rights under SELinux. SELinux has been progressively making its way to Android. It can be a pain to configure but is now here to stay. Because disabling SELinux is never a solution, R√©my & Guillaume started to study it‚Äôs mechanism as they worked on rom cooking.

Headline: Custom Lint rules ‚Äì A journey towards cleaner code, talk by Andr√© Diermann
Text:
Andr√© Diermann

Every Android Developer is using it all the time: Lint. It‚Äôs deeply integrated into Android Studio and features more than 200 default checks. It‚Äôs possible to extend this powerful tool, but how? By writing custom Lint rules for large enterprise Android projects for more than two years now, Andr√© gained comprehensive hands-on experience with Lint. Unfortunately official documentation on how to write custom Lint rules is rare and deprecated. When it comes to testing or operating these rules you won‚Äôt find any official documentation.
Speaker: Andr√© Diermann
Description: Every Android Developer is using it all the time: Lint. It‚Äôs deeply integrated into Android Studio and features more than 200 default checks. It‚Äôs possible to extend this powerful tool, but how? By writing custom Lint rules for large enterprise Android projects for more than two years now, Andr√© gained comprehensive hands-on experience with Lint. Unfortunately official documentation on how to write custom Lint rules is rare and deprecated. When it comes to testing or operating these rules you won‚Äôt find any official documentation.

Headline: Blendle‚Äôs Android lead Jolanda Verhoef
Text:
Jolanda Verhoef

When starting at Blendle, Jolanda had a fresh chance to build an Android application from the ground up. She could finally use all the libraries she had wanted to use for a long time. At this point in time, Jolanda is using Butterknife, Universal Image Loader, OkHttp, GSon, EventBus, RxAndroid / RxJava, Mosby, Icepick, FragmentArgs, and a lot of UI libraries on top of that. Each of those libraries has its perks and Jolanda is eager to share with you her experiences.
Speaker: Jolanda Verhoef

Each of those libraries has its perks and Jolanda is eager to share with you her experiences.

Headline: Doze Mode & App Standby in Android M
Text:
David V√°vra

Android Marshmallow brings major changes to the platform which can limit functionality of existing apps. If you are doing any background work in your app, your app will be affected by Doze & App Standby in favour of longer battery life. Let‚Äôs see what APIs will be limited and what are the best practices for scheduling background tasks.
Speaker: David V√°vra
Description: Android Marshmallow brings major changes to the platform which can limit functionality of existing apps. If you are doing any background work in your app, your app will be affected by Doze & App Standby in favour of longer battery life. Let‚Äôs see what APIs will be limited and what are the best practices for scheduling background tasks.

Headline: Android, The World Phone
Text:
Corey Latislaw

Emerging markets are where most of the mobile growth over the next decade will occur, but there are too few solutions that specifically target (or even consider) their needs. Building solutions that serve all of your customers will become increasingly more important. In this session Corey will explore emerging use cases, technical challenges, and social challenges you will encounter when serving these markets. You will walk away with guidelines to write globally inclusive applications in order to make a broader global impact.
Speaker: Corey Latislaw
Description: Emerging markets are where most of the mobile growth over the next decade will occur, but there are too few solutions that specifically target (or even consider) their needs. Building solutions that serve all of your customers will become increasingly more important. In this session Corey will explore emerging use cases, technical challenges, and social challenges you will encounter when serving these markets. You will walk away with guidelines to write globally inclusive applications in order to make a broader global impact.

Headline: Expressive functional testing with Espresso
Text:
Maciej G√≥rski

Maciej will show you his approach towards functional testing with Espresso and a bit of dependency inversion magic. Do you have a feeling testing network error conditions is hard or cumbersome when done manually? Turns out it‚Äôs even easier to automatically test it than ‚Äúthe happy path‚Äù. You will see real code from production app, so remember to drink a shot of espresso before joining this session.
Speaker: Maciej G√≥rski

Headline: Android Reverse Engineering with ARES
Text:
Dario Incalza

In this talk Dario Incalza will shed a light on Reverse engineering Android applications: tools and countermeasures. Dario has developed a tool to ease Android reverse engineering. It is useful to inspect malware suspected applications. Work is an ongoing opensource project.
Speaker: Dario Incalza
Description: In this talk Dario Incalza will shed a light on Reverse engineering Android applications: tools and countermeasures. Dario has developed a tool to ease Android reverse engineering. It is useful to inspect malware suspected applications. Work is an ongoing opensource project.

Headline: Android and Offline Data
Text:
Christopher Pick

Some higher level background and experience from building two very different applications for use in an offline environment. From micro services to orchestration/aggregating services. Discuss implications of using each, and some of the storage mechanisms that can be used to handle those services. Utilizing sync adapters, content providers, sqlite databases to ORMs.. This will be pretty light on code, heavy on theory for achieving offline functionality.
Speaker: Christopher Pick
Description: Some higher level background and experience from building two very different applications for use in an offline environment. From micro services to orchestration/aggregating services. Discuss implications of using each, and some of the storage mechanisms that can be used to handle those services. Utilizing sync adapters, content providers, sqlite databases to ORMs.. This will be pretty light on code, heavy on theory for achieving offline functionality.

Headline: Xamarin for Android developers
Text:
Aleksander Piotrowski

Most of us heard about Xamarin and very often ignored it as yet another phonegap clone. Let‚Äôs compare Xamarin with Android development as we know it today and see how (un)fair this this comparison really is. Most recently Applause created an SDK component for Xamarin and found out this platform gives us all the tools mature dev platform should have like strong leadership, lively community, including their own Jake Wharton ;-), ‚Äúmodern‚Äù IDE, cool programming language, erm, C# that is üòâ Sadly it‚Äôs not ‚Äúwrite once and run everywhere‚Äù but Xamarin, if used correctly, can be ‚Äúwrite once, tweak a bit, and run everywhere‚Äù.
Speaker: Aleksander Piotrowski

Headline: Understanding Gradle for Android
Text:
Kevin Pelgrims

As a Gradle enthusiast, it pains Kevin Pelgrims to see that Android developers do not understand how Gradle works, even if it could make their work significantly easier. Gradle is capable of a lot more than just building your Android apps or libraries. You can automate every aspect of your build process: versioning, APK renaming and shrinking, generating test reports, ‚Ä¶
Speaker: Kevin Pelgrims

Gradle is capable of a lot more than just building your Android apps or libraries. You can automate every aspect of your build process: versioning, APK renaming and shrinking, generating test reports, ‚Ä¶

Headline: Lollipop Animations
Text:
Matt Compton

Many applications exclude animations ‚Äì deeming them unnecessary or too costly or not ‚Äú‚Äùworth it‚Äù‚Äù. Animations can delight users and help craft a positive experience inside of an app, so Matt wants to show beginners how simple and easy it is to add meaningful animations to an existing application. Animation usage also swings in the opposite direction ‚Äì some apps over-use and overwhelm a user with unnecessary or annoying animations. Matt is hoping to show a simple middle-ground, showing you how to implement the newest Android animations and when to use them.
Speaker: Matt Compton

Matt is hoping to show a simple middle-ground, showing you how to implement the newest Android animations and when to use them.

Headline: Right-to-Left Languages in Android
Text:
Danny Preussler

What happens when the language supported is a right-to-left one like hebrew. How does it affect the UI? What are the implications and how can developers and even designers overcome certain pitfalls. Working at Groupon, Danny Preussler will show that with some simple changes the app could have decent RTL support. Ever reversed a viewpager or a calendar?
Speaker: Danny Preussler
Description: What happens when the language supported is a right-to-left one like hebrew. How does it affect the UI? What are the implications and how can developers and even designers overcome certain pitfalls. Working at Groupon, Danny Preussler will show that with some simple changes the app could have decent RTL support. Ever reversed a viewpager or a calendar?

Headline: Big Android BBQ Europe 2015 Day 2
Text: Doors open / registration

Headline: 10 ways to improve your Android app performance
Text:
Boris Farber

As a Developer Advocate at Google, Boris Farber is exposed to various Android apps. He brings together several rules of thumb: working, best practice solutions for improving your Android app performance, while avoiding the common pitfalls. This talk will deal with: Activity leaks, scrolling, concurrency APIs, deprecation, JNI, architecture, miscellany.
Speaker: Boris Farber
Description: As a Developer Advocate at Google, Boris Farber is exposed to various Android apps. He brings together several rules of thumb: working, best practice solutions for improving your Android app performance, while avoiding the common pitfalls. This talk will deal with: Activity leaks, scrolling, concurrency APIs, deprecation, JNI, architecture, miscellany.

Headline: Interfacing with Sensors
Text:
Michael Schloh von Bennewitz

This session describes the science of Android environment sensing with respect to the IoT. It teaches characteristic theory of IoT components as well as making development recommendations for use cases like Home Automation or Sport Wearables. A series of live demonstrations serve to illustrate the topic at hand.
Speaker: Michael Schloh von Bennewitz
Description: This session describes the science of Android environment sensing with respect to the IoT. It teaches characteristic theory of IoT components as well as making development recommendations for use cases like Home Automation or Sport Wearables. A series of live demonstrations serve to illustrate the topic at hand.

Headline: Do Anything You Want to Any ChromeCast Screen, Natively
Text:
Maarten Edgar

A hands-on tour to getting a separately driven SurfaceView to display on a ChromeCast through Android programming using the latest, just released ChromeCast API‚Äôs, without any HTML programming or even having to register the ChromeCast. Using his experience gained from having developed a Google Play released app, Maarten will show attendees how to use their current knowledge of Android programming to make whatever they want appear on any HDMI display device. They will be guided through the installation of the necessary libraries and Android Studio setup, the different methods of getting content to show up on the ChromeCast and the use of the latest post I/O 2015 released API‚Äôs to literally display anything they can program on their big screen.
Speaker: Maarten Edgar

Headline: Testing it and loving it
Text:
Zan Markan

Looking at most Android projects lying around on github, Zan Markan is sad to see testing has not taken the front row seat it deserves ‚Äì most projects still sport the auto generated stub for ApplicationTestCase. Zan will go through the testing journey with some examples on what to test, how to write tests, and trying to make sense of all the tools that enable our testing. Unit testing, Robolectric, Espresso, Calabash, etc‚Ä¶
Speaker: Zan Markan
Description: Looking at most Android projects lying around on github, Zan Markan is sad to see testing has not taken the front row seat it deserves ‚Äì most projects still sport the auto generated stub for ApplicationTestCase. Zan will go through the testing journey with some examples on what to test, how to write tests, and trying to make sense of all the tools that enable our testing. Unit testing, Robolectric, Espresso, Calabash, etc‚Ä¶

Headline: Let‚Äôs Play! ‚Äì Building a VR Sandbox
Text:
Etienne Caron

Using a combination of scripting and live shader updates over Firebase, combined with off the shelf devices such as Project Tango tablets and Android Wear devices, Etienne Caron has built and will demonstrate an Android toolchain allowing developers to get instant feedback when building VR spaces and experiences in the Android ecosystem.
Speaker: Etienne Caron
Description: Using a combination of scripting and live shader updates over Firebase, combined with off the shelf devices such as Project Tango tablets and Android Wear devices, Etienne Caron has built and will demonstrate an Android toolchain allowing developers to get instant feedback when building VR spaces and experiences in the Android ecosystem.

Headline: Event Buses: The @channel of Android Architecture
Text:
Bill Phillips

Channel notifications. If you know them, you probably have an opinion about them. Maybe they‚Äôre annoying and contribute to organizational noise. Maybe they help you get important things done quickly.

Start Date: Event buses. If you know them, you probably have an opinion about them. Maybe they‚Äôre annoying and contribute to organizational noise. Maybe they help you get important things done quickly.

Headline: Mission Relevance-oriented notification design
Text:
Anke Hans

Anke‚Äôs personal response to mobile notifications became unsatisfying so she researched mobile notification culture and became a self-proclaimed notification philosopher.

Start Date: Current notification design is realtime driven. Because smartphone users are generally incapable of processing large amounts of realtime stimuli, this design is causing a new chronic low-level stress called notification stress. A relevance-oriented notification design would better suit the individual information needs of smartphone users.
Tag: Anke‚Äôs personal response to mobile notifications became unsatisfying so she researched mobile notification culture and became a self-proclaimed notification philosopher. Current notification design is realtime driven. Because smartphone users are generally incapable of processing large amounts of realtime stimuli, this design is causing a new chronic low-level stress called notification stress. A relevance-oriented notification design would better suit the individual information needs of smartphone users.

Headline: IPC & AIDL: Sexy, not a curse
Text:
Yonatan Levin

Understanding more about the architecture and what is actually going on in the platform will help you write better applications (Chet Haase and Romain Guy). Yonatan Levin wants to take a moment and go deep into the Android IPC architecture, he will start the journey with interprocess communication throughout the small talk with Binder via AIDL all the way to the service on separate process and finish with a Star wars application with a great performance.
Speaker: Yonatan Levin
Description: Understanding more about the architecture and what is actually going on in the platform will help you write better applications (Chet Haase and Romain Guy). Headline: Striptease of The Android Permissions System
Text:
Aliz√©e Penel & Alexis Rosovsky

In the current context where customers are more sensible about protecting their privacy, our duty as developers is to

Start Date: consider security in our developments. Google did understand this global problematic and provides in Android OS
different kinds of security systems: selinux, permissions system, etc.
Throughout this talk, Aliz√©e Penel & Alexis Rosovsky are going to present how the Android permission system is implemented, all the way from the kernel to the application layer.
Tag: In the current context where customers are more sensible about protecting their privacy, our duty as developers is to consider security in our developments. Google did understand this global problematic and provides in Android OS different kinds of security systems: selinux, permissions system, etc. Throughout this talk, Aliz√©e Penel & Alexis Rosovsky are going to present how the Android permission system is implemented, all the way from the kernel to the application layer.

Headline: With a little help from my libs
Text:
Royi Benyossef

Android‚Äôs support libraries have become a necessity for most developers. They contain a veritable cornucopia of essentials components, abilities and functionalities essential for creating a cohesive premium user experience, not only for the latest and greatest devices and API levels but for the majority of end-users. Royi Benyossef will explain that the only problem is that most developers only know a fraction of the abilities offered to them and do not posses the basic knowledge on where to find what.

Start Date: This session is aimed at educating the developers regarding the tools that the support libraries offer as well as examples on how to use them.
Tag: Android‚Äôs support libraries have become a necessity for most developers. They contain a veritable cornucopia of essentials components, abilities and functionalities essential for creating a cohesive premium user experience, not only for the latest and greatest devices and API levels but for the majority of end-users. Royi Benyossef will explain that the only problem is that most developers only know a fraction of the abilities offered to them and do not posses the basic knowledge on where to find what. This session is aimed at educating the developers regarding the tools that the support libraries offer as well as examples on how to use them.

Headline: Zalando App Failures and Retrospectives
Text:
Raymond Chenon

Joining Zalando before the IPO when the Android app was started by only 2 backend developers, Raymond will share with you ‚ÄòBest Practices‚Äô and the mistakes they learnt from. In this session, Raymond will share some stories on how the most unexpected tiny error had the biggest impact on production. Here is the list : ‚Äì Google Play Store release that went wrong before being featured as Editors‚Äô Choice. ‚Äì the wrong country of the user . ‚Äì Apps Deep Links ‚Äì Wrong app title. A library overrides your app title in a language not covered by your app. ‚Äì the big refactoring that went wrong. Learn how to scope a refactoring. ‚Äì Marshmallow permissions
